a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 17 powr 13 - 17"
shows  "n mod 10 = 0"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Determine the units digit of $17^{13} - 17$. The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 The units digit of $17^3 - 17$ is the same as the units digit as $7^{13} - 7$.
 To find the units digit of $7^{13}$, we look at the first few powers of 7 modulo 10: \begin{align} 7^0 &\equiv 1, \\ 7^1 &\equiv 7, \\ 7^2 &\equiv 7 \cdot 7 \equiv 49 \equiv 9, \\ 7^3 &\equiv 7 \cdot 9 \equiv 63 \equiv 3, \\
 7^4 &\equiv 7 \cdot 3 \equiv 21 \equiv 1 \pmod{10}. \end{align} Since $7^4 \equiv 1 \pmod{10}$, the remainders become periodic, with period 4. Since $13 \equiv 1 \pmod{4}$, $7^{13} \equiv 7 \pmod{10}$, so the units digit of $7^{13} - 7$ is $\boxed{0}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 17 powr 13 - 17"
shows  "n mod 10 = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: What is the remainder when $17^{13} - 17$ is divided by 10? The final answer is 0.

 *)

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = 17 powr 13"
and h1 : "b = 17"
shows  "digit (a - b) 0 = 0"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Determine the units digit of $17^{13} - 17$. The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 The units digit of $17^3 - 17$ is the same as the units digit as $7^{13} - 7$.
 To find the units digit of $7^{13}$, we look at the first few powers of 7 modulo 10: \begin{align} 7^0 &\equiv 1, \\ 7^1 &\equiv 7, \\ 7^2 &\equiv 7 \cdot 7 \equiv 49 \equiv 9, \\ 7^3 &\equiv 7 \cdot 9 \equiv 63 \equiv 3, \\
 7^4 &\equiv 7 \cdot 3 \equiv 21 \equiv 1 \pmod{10}. \end{align} Since $7^4 \equiv 1 \pmod{10}$, the remainders become periodic, with period 4. Since $13 \equiv 1 \pmod{4}$, $7^{13} \equiv 7 \pmod{10}$, so the units digit of $7^{13} - 7$ is $\boxed{0}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = 17 powr 13"
and h1 : "b = 17"
shows  "digit (a - b) 0 = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find the units digit of the number $17^{13} - 17$. The final answer is $0$.

natural solution: The units digit of $17^3 - 17$ is the same as the units digit as $7^{13} - 7$.

To find the units digit of $7^{13}$, we look at the first few powers of 7 modulo 10: \begin{align} 7^0 &\equiv 1, \\ 7^1 &\equiv 7, \\ 7^2 &\equiv 7 \cdot 7 \equiv 49 \equiv 9, \\ 7^3 &\equiv 7 \cdot 9 \equiv 63 \equiv 3, \\

7^4 &\equiv 7 \cdot 3 \equiv 21 \equiv 1 \pmod{10}. \end{align} Since $7^4 \equiv 1 \pmod{10}$, the remainders become periodic, with period 4. Since $13 \equiv 1 \pmod{4}$, $7^{13} \equiv 7 \pmod{10}$, so the units digit of $7^{13} - 7$ is $\boxed{0}$.
